segments.text: Out of 15 seconds?
No.
When you see Tex at Treadwell, I'll tell him I said, hi, boss, because when I was with the National Oceanographic Data Center, I didn't have a boss.
I had a 10-agency advisory board, but the Navy had the administrative overview
And Tex and I used to wave in our arms at each other and scream and yell.
So when we were out at a reception or if I ever had a chance, I would become very differential and say, yes, boss, no, boss.
I miss him.
He's a wonderful guy.
Is there anything you'd like to add to the interview?
Anything you can think of I missed that you'd like to put on tape?
Excuse me, I have one more question before I let you do that.
There is now talk about centralizing research in oceanography under one agency and one head.
What is your opinion of that?
Well, I don't really know what that means.
I don't know how you could do it to begin with because the agencies in the government
who have a mission that involves the ocean.
You probably could have a monolithic department where you had geological survey, Bureau of Land Management, NOAA.
Certainly you couldn't have the Navy, the Coast Guard, Fish and Wildlife Service.
Then over here you have academia.
And we have to be very careful there that we don't try to impose the mission-oriented aspects if we're going to keep abreast in technology.
So you have NSF and ONR and Ford Foundation and Rockefeller Foundation.
And then these agencies, of course, do.
So I can't envision it.
After 30 years in the government, I still...
I can't envision a monolithic organization in the marine sciences if I understand your question correctly.
That's really all I have.
Anything you'd like to add to the table?
Gosh, no.
I'm happy to answer questions.
That's it.
